title: Speech acts: Constative and performative - Colleen Glenney Boggs

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between constatives and performatives, as defined by J.L. Austin?

options.label: A
options.text: Constatives are sentences that describe something as true or false, while performatives are sentences that convey a message.

options.label: B
options.text: Constatives are sentences that denote an action, while performatives are sentences that describe something as true or false.

options.label: C
options.text: Constatives are sentences that inspire actions, while performatives are sentences that convey a message.

options.label: D
options.text: Constatives are sentences that convey a message, while performatives are sentences that denote an action.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a true constative?
What is an example of a false constative?
What is an example of a performative?
What is an example of a speech act?

options.label: A
options.text: Ordering, promising, apologizing, warning, sentencing, christening, and marrying.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of felicity conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the effectiveness of performatives.

options.label: B
options.text: To classify performatives as true or false constatives.

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the difference between constatives and performatives.

multiple-choice.question: What are the felicity conditions for performatives?

options.label: A
options.text: Proper authority, understanding, clarity, and executability.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a felicity condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The mayor showing up to the wedding and saying, "By the power vested in me as mayor of the city, I name this gazebo 'The Mayor's Pizza Palace'."

options.label: B
options.text: The life guard responding with another performative, sentencing the teenagers to be banished from the pool for the rest of the day.

options.label: C
options.text: The teenagers racing to the high dive and ignoring the "No running" sign.

options.label: D
options.text: The couple saying the words, "I do."

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of respecting the power of words?

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the effectiveness of performatives.

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the difference between constatives and performatives.

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid consequences of breaking performatives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of breaking performatives?

options.label: B
options.text: The person breaking the performative is sentenced to be banished from the pool for the rest of the day.

options.label: C
options.text: The person breaking the performative is forced to apologize and promise to never break the performative again.

options.label: D
options.text: The person breaking the performative is ignored.

title: The most groundbreaking scientist you've never heard of - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What was the main contribution of Nicolas Steno to the field of geology?

options.label: A
options.text: He developed the concept of plate tectonics.

options.label: B
options.text: He refuted Descartes' idea that the pineal gland was the seat of the soul.

options.label: C
options.text: He developed the theory of uniformitarianism.

options.label: D
options.text: He discovered the duct in animal skulls that sends saliva to the mouth.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Steno's discovery of the duct in animal skulls?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the development of plate tectonics.

options.label: B
options.text: It refuted Descartes' idea that the pineal gland was the seat of the soul.

options.label: C
options.text: It provided evidence for the concept of uniformitarianism.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a better understanding of the structure of organs shared across species.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between Steno's approach to science and that of Descartes?

options.label: A
options.text: Steno emphasized the role of reason in scientific inquiry, while Descartes emphasized the role of observation.

options.label: B
options.text: Steno emphasized the role of observation in scientific inquiry, while Descartes emphasized the role of reason.

options.label: C
options.text: Steno and Descartes had similar approaches to science.

options.label: D
options.text: Steno's approach was more empirical, while Descartes' approach was more theoretical.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Steno's development of stratigraphy?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the development of plate tectonics.

options.label: B
options.text: It provided evidence for the concept of uniformitarianism.

options.label: C
options.text: It allowed scientists to understand the structure of the Earth's crust.

options.label: D
options.text: It refuted Descartes' idea that the pineal gland was the seat of the soul.

multiple-choice.question: Who was influenced by Steno's work on stratigraphy?

options.label: C
options.text: Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What was the main idea of uniformitarianism?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's past was shaped by processes that are still observable today.

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth's past was shaped by processes that are no longer observable today.

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's past was shaped by processes that are different from those that shape the present.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's past was shaped by processes that are similar to those that shape the present.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Steno's work for the field of biology?

options.label: A
options.text: It provided a framework for understanding the origin and extinction of species over time.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the development of plate tectonics.

options.label: C
options.text: It refuted to the development of the theory of evolution.

options.label: D
options.text: It refuted Descartes' idea that the pineal gland was the seat of the soul.

multiple-choice.question: Who was influenced by Steno's work on uniformitarianism?

options.label: B
options.text: Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between Steno's approach to science and that of his contemporaries?

options.label: A
options.text: Steno emphasized the role of reason in scientific inquiry, while his contemporaries emphasized the role of observation.

options.label: B
options.text: Steno emphasized the role of observation in scientific inquiry, while his contemporaries emphasized the role of reason.

options.label: C
options.text: Steno and his contemporaries had similar approaches to science.

options.label: D
options.text: Steno's approach was more empirical, while his contemporaries' approach was more theoretical.

multiple-choice.question: What was Steno's maxim regarding the pursuit of truth?

options.label: A
options.text: The pursuit of truth is a rational endeavor.

options.label: B
options.text: The pursuit of truth is an empirical endeavor.

options.label: C
options.text: The pursuit of truth is a beautiful and unknown endeavor.

options.label: D
options.text: The pursuit of truth is a tedious and time-consuming endeavor.

title: Was Leonardo da Vinci dyslexic?

multiple-choice.question: Why did Leonardo da Vinci write his journal entries in reverse?

options.label: A
options.text: As a deliberate form of code

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was a result of his dyslexia

options.label: D
options.text: As a form of artistic expression

multiple-choice.question: What is dyslexia, according to Professor Maryanne Wolf?

options.label: A
options.text: A learning disability that impairs word recognition

options.label: B
options.text: An inherited learning disability that impairs reading and writing skills

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that affects only left-handed individuals

multiple-choice.question: Which hemisphere of the brain governs word recognition?
Why did Professor Wolf conduct an experiment with four individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: To test her theory about Da Vinci's mirror writing

options.label: B
options.text: To study the effects of dyslexia on writing skills

options.label: C
options.text: To compare the writing skills of left-handers and right-handers

options.label: D
options.text: To explore the relationship between mirror writing and artistic expression

multiple-choice.question: What was the main finding of Professor Wolf's experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That left-handers were faster than right-handers

options.label: B
options.text: That dyslexics were quicker than the others

options.label: C
options.text: That mirror writing is a result of a deliberate code

options.label: D
options.text: That word recognition is improved by mirror writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Da Vinci's mirror writing, according to Professor Wolf?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a form of artistic expression

options.label: B
options.text: It is a deliberate form of code

options.label: C
options.text: It is a result of a natural neurological process

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of genius

multiple-choice.question: How many individuals participated in Professor Wolf's experiment?
What is the relationship between dyslexia and mirror writing, according to Professor Wolf?

options.label: C
options.text: Dyslexics are more naturally able to mirror-write

options.label: D
options.text: Mirror writing is a result of dyslexia

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the right hemisphere in the brain, according to Professor Wolf?

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze space and geometrical shapes

multiple-choice.question: What is the conclusion of Professor Wolf's experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That Da Vinci's mirror writing was a deliberate code

options.label: B
options.text: That dyslexics are more naturally able to mirror-write

options.label: C
options.text: That left-handers are faster than right-handers

options.label: D
options.text: That mirror writing is a result of a deliberate code

title: Your genes are not your fate - Dean Ornish

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to change our genes according to the speaker?

options.label: C

title: Can we domesticate germs? - Paul Ewald

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To discuss the concept of using evolution to design disease organisms to be less harmful.

options.label: B
options.text: To present a new treatment for malaria.

options.label: C
options.text: To discuss the importance of clean water in preventing disease.

options.label: D
options.text: To explain the concept of antibiotic resistance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between waterborne transmission and the harm caused by diarrheal diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Waterborne transmission leads to more severe disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Waterborne transmission leads to milder disease.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no relationship between waterborne transmission and disease severity.

options.label: D
options.text: Waterborne transmission is not a significant factor in disease severity.

options.label: B
options.text: The organism remained the same in all countries.

options.label: C
options.text: The organism evolved to be milder in countries with clean water supplies.

options.label: D
options.text: The organism evolved to be more harmful in countries with poor water quality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of controlling diarrheal diseases through evolution?

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using evolution to control disease?

options.label: B
options.text: A strong economy leads to increased transmission.

options.label: C
options.text: A weak economy leads to increased transmission.

options.label: D
options.text: Economic changes can lead to evolutionary changes in the virus.
